content.description: Start just left below giant prow, under the roof.  Clip high and solve the movement through lots of steep terrain and one fixed draw.
Step off ledge carefully, but easy ground to first bolt.  Then climb through wild steep terrain out left (look for good feet even further left), then right again to face above.  Fun and interesting.
Good fingers and large holds gets you to thinner moves in a stem. Delicate step beck left to a less than awesome finish on licheny rock, but it was worth getting here. Well bolted.
content.location: Starts in a right facing dihedral just left of splitter crack "Feasting on Saints".

content.description: If you can stem, this route is or you.   If you have never climbed a trad stembox, good luck.  This corner system is steep and wily.
content.location: Far right of Heavenly Buttress, in a nook next to "South of Heaven".

content.description:
Great face climbing through neat features.  Start up shallow corner to wide layback, then pull short overlap to steep face. Use a set of left-hand underclings and devious footholds to reach for good edges.  Fun, balancy climbing that will challenge your ability to commit to movement. 

  One can avoid the crux moves by traversing far right after clipping the 5th bolt, but that's no fun.
content.location: Left side of walkway at base of cliff.

content.description:
Start under large block and ashy layer at first 5 feet.  Find little foot rock and mantle over block! 

  Then great face climbing.
content.location: center of walkway at base of wall.

content.description: Left side of Heavenly Buttress, climb through a few blocky ledges to a very clean layback corner that heads right.  Climbs really nice.
content.protection: Bring a few wires and cams from 00 to "1.

content.description: Mixed bag of climbing styles. Lots of barely overhanging terrain through big power-balance moves to delicate up high. Fun!!!
content.location: Start same as for After-Life, but head right.

content.description: Start as for 7th Heaven, clip 2 bolts, then head right up to blocky ledge at base of finger splitter.
content.protection: Bring tips to finger sized gear, and wires.

content.description: Start by stepping onto a ledge to reach a splitter finger crack that leads to hands and maybe fists through a steep bulge with a horn on the left. Awesome!
content.protection: Single rack from wires or zeros to hands. An extra 0 or 00 is useful. One bolt out right protects the crux move, and keeps the rope clean out of the crack. Anchor shared with "St. Peters Corner"
content.location: Splitter to the right of of a right facing dihedral.Â

content.description: Start in a steep groove-crack through 3 bolts to ramp.  Then technical face climbing above on very dark rock.
content.location: First route on Heavenly Buttress right, starts from grassy shelf just before it steps down to ashy ramp.

content.description: Clip first bolt of Heaven Sent, then head hard right through three more bolts that lead to base of corner.  The crack is fun 5.9 for 50 more feet.
content.protection: single rack from wires to #1 camalot.
content.location: Same start as for Heaven Sent.

content.description: Start just right of Dark Angel, at a blunt, lichen-covered arete.  tricky movement at 2nd bolt leads to a ramp before the face-action.  Great techy movement around a dime-crack seam, keeps you on your toes.
content.location: Right side route below black varnished face.

content.description: Dihedral in center of wall, techy movement through steep terrain, keep your feet active!!
content.protection: doubles from 00 to .5 camalots.  Wires too.  Bring one Gold Camalot for topout.
content.location: Start by stepping off ground onto ashy block, then onto basalt ledge.  Then cruise up the corner.  Bring draws and patience.

content.description:
North Facing wall with a wide variety of routes. The highest concentration of trad lines are found here, and a couple really good 5.12s.  

  A good warm season destination. In the summer, the left side of the wall is in the sun until maybe 10:30am. Also, the far right side of the wall goes into the sun in late afternoon.  In the shoulder season, very little sun on this wall.
